Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I stood at the foot of Mr. Patel’s bed, carefully helping him sit up. His surgery had left him weak, and every movement needed my full attention. As a nursing assistant, I knew my duty was to make sure he was safe and comfortable, especially now when he needed extra help to get dressed and move around. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder from my family about the festival. Today was the start of Navratri, and my family had already traveled hours to the temple. They expected me to join them, to participate in the rituals and offerings, to be present for the prayers that only happen once a year. My heart ached with the weight of both worlds. I could see the trust in Mr. Patel’s eyes, and I could hear my mother’s voice in my mind, urging me not to miss the festival. I felt torn, caught between the needs of my patient and the pull of my faith, unsure which path to follow as the minutes ticked by.
